metadata.title: LA-CALC-4.1 Rectilinear Motion
metadata.creator: jason_wang
metadata.abstract: This document is for testing purposes only. The material that is presented here should be treated as an example only.

stack.p: Solve problems about motion along a line using the power of differential calculus. For example, given the position of a particle as a function of time s(t), find the particle's maximum velocity.
The position of a particle moving along the x-axis is given by $s(t)=t^3-6t^2+9t$, where $t \geq 0$. When is the particle "speeding up"?

button.name: btn
button.onClick: stepsController:toggleStep(1)

stack.name: cont
stack.p: To get velocity $v(t)$, we solve the first derivative of $s(t)$.
Now we can get the inital velocity, which help us graph: $v(0)=9$
Also, we need to find the time(s) where velocity is 0.

button.name: btn
button.onClick: stepsController:toggleStep(2)

stack.name: cont
stack.p: To get acceleration, we will need to calculate the first derivative of $v(t)$.
Then find the time where acceleration is 0.
Therefore, the particle "speeding up" at $1<t<2$ and $t>3$

button.name: btn
button.onClick: stepsController:toggleStep(3)

stack.name: cont

button.name: sButton
vButton
aButton
btn
button.onClick: stepsController:toggleStep(4)

column.p: A particle moves along the x-axis so that at any time $t \geq 0$ its velocity is given by $v(t)=-t^3+6t^2+2t$.
At What value of $t$ does the particle obtain its maximum acceleration?

stack.name: fullSolution
stack.p: To get the function of acceleration, solve the first derivative of $v(t)$:
Solve the first derivative of $a(t)$ to get max/min value:
In order to know if 2 is maximum, we need to solve the second derivative of $a(t)$:
Since $a''(t)$ always less than 0, thus $t=2$ is the maximum acceleration.

btn

Try again." attempt = attempt + 1 if attempt >= max then answerStack.Style.Visibility = "visible" end else feedback.Style.Visibility = "visible" feedback.Text = "Correct, Good Job!" end

column.p: A particle moves along a number line (not shown) for $t \geq 0$. Its position function $s(t)$ is shown in blue, its velocity function $v(t)$ is in red, and its acceleration function $a(t)$ is in green. All are graphed with respect to time $t$ in seconds.
With the graphs as an aid, answer the questions below.

button.name: btn
button.onClick: mqController:toggleStep(1)

column.p: How many units per second is the initial velocity of the particle?

button.name: btn
button.onClick: mqController:toggleStep(2)

column.p: The particle is moving to the right when $t \in$ __________. (Enter a range like $[3,63)$)

stack.name: fullSolution
stack.p: The particle is moving to the right when velocity $v(t)>0$
So, $time$ between 0 and 1 (exclusive), which answer is $[0,1)$

button.name: btn
button.onClick: mqController:toggleStep(3)

column.p: The total distance tranveled by the particle for $t \in [0,3]$ is ______ units.

stack.name: fullSolution
stack.p: Total distance means the displacement travelled ignoring directions. For example:
If you travel 3 units to the right and 1 unit to the left. The displacement would be 2, but total distance would be 4.
Now look at the graph, $v(t)$ became negative after 1, which means the particle changes the direction at 1.
Time between 0 and 1, $s(t)$ shows the particle has traveled 2 units forward, and 0.5 unit backward from 1 to 3.
Therefore, the total distance traveled by the particle for $t \in [0,3]$ is $2 + 0.5 = 2.5$ units.

column.p: The position of a particle moving along a number line is given by
where t is time in seconds.
The particle moves both left and right in the first six seconds. What's the total distance traveled by the particle for $0 \leq t \leq 6$?

stack.name: fullSolution
stack.p: First, we need to know when the particle is moving on the right and left.
To do that, we need to get the velocity function, so do the first derivative of $s(t)$:
Solve for t-intersections of $v(t)$ to get direction changing point.
Then, we solve for the distance for every segment:

p.b: Finally, the sum of all distances: $4\frac{2}{3} + 21\frac{1}{3}+ 4\frac{2}{3} = 30\frac{2}{3}$
